sections: Corporate law firms and consultants rake in hundreds of millions of dollars busting unions every year, and thanks to a legal loophole, the businesses that hire them don’t have to disclose these controversial activities. The Persuader Rule, a provision of the Protecting the Right to Organize (PRO) Act, a major labor reform bill making its way through Congress, would require companies to disclose when they hire union-busting law firms or consultants during union drives — but the American Bar Association (ABA), the country’s largest legal association, has long opposed the potential rule.

Now, however, in a major rebuke to the ABA, law students and young attorneys are joining forces with some of the country’s largest labor unions to declare, “It’s time to close a loophole that lets lawyers campaign against unions in secret.”
Find out the details of that effort and much more in today’s Midday Poster below, exclusively for subscribers!

On Wednesday, eight organizations including lawyers, legal organizations, and some of the country’s biggest labor unions sent a letter to Congress in support of the Protecting the Right to Organize (PRO) Act and rebuking the
the opposition of American Bar Association
(ABA), the country’s largest legal association, to some provisions of the legislation.

“It’s time to close a loophole that lets lawyers campaign against unions in secret,” said Molly Coleman, executive director of People’s Parity Project, an organization of law students and young attorneys working to reform the legal profession, which organized the
“Our professional ethics shouldn’t become just another weapon companies use against their employees.”

Other signatories include the American Federation of Teachers, the Service Employees International Union, and the National Employment Lawyers Association. The letter was sent to the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions, where the PRO Act is currently under consideration.

The ABA has long opposed the Persuader Rule, a provision of the PRO Act that would require companies to disclose when they hire union-busting law firms or consultants during union drives. Corporate law firms rake in hundreds of millions of dollars busting unions every year, and legal ethics experts believe
the ABA’s opposition to the Persuader Rule,

According to the letter just sent to Congress, “workers often have no idea that anti-union talking points are crafted by third parties — information that, like disclosure requirements on campaign advertisements, informs workers’ votes.”

The Persuader Rule would change those disclosure requirements to mandate that companies publicly disclose any time they hire firms to advise them during union elections, even if those firms don’t directly interact with employees.

“Union-busting consultants script employers’ anti-union campaigns from start to finish,” said Sejal Singh, an organizer with the People’s Parity Project. “Just like voters deserve to know who’s flooding the airwaves during a Presidential election, workers deserve to know who’s writing the threatening texts they get every day and coaching their bosses on how to scare workers into voting against the union while just toeing the legal line. Congress shouldn’t give modern-day Pinkertons a pass just because they happen to be lawyers.”

to flip those senators  — but even if they signed on, the Senate would need to reform the filibuster to pass the bill, since it is unlikely that any of the 50 Republicans in the Senate would back it. President Joe Biden
enact the Persuader Rule via executive order.

On this day in 2015, President Barack Obama

the formal re-establishment of diplomatic relations with Cuba. The U.S. planned to relax some restrictions on the country and reopen an embassy in the island nation for the first time since 1961. The move came after the Obama State Department removed Cuba from its list of state sponsors of terrorism.

“Americans and Cubans alike are ready to move forward. I believe it’s time for Congress to do the same,” said Obama, who visited the country the following year, becoming the first sitting president to do so in almost a century. “We’ve already seen members from both parties begin that work.”

When Donald Trump took office, however, he altered course to apply “maximum pressure” on Cuba. In June 2017, he reimposed travel and business restrictions on the country and the following September, cut embassy staff in half. Days before Trump left office, his state department redesignated Cuba a state sponsor of terrorism.
On the campaign trail, Joe Biden
Trump’s Cuba policy as an “abject failure.” In March, however, Biden press secretary Jen Psaki
changing course was “not a priority” for the new administration. Despite
, he has not shifted course nearly half a year into his administration.

• SUPREME COURT DEALS HEAVY BLOWS TO DEMOCRACY:
The Supreme Court recently decided two cases that could have serious negative consequences for American democracy. In
along party lines, the court struck down a California law requiring nonprofits to disclose their donors to state officials. In

, the court upheld two controversial Arizona voter suppression laws — one that invalidated ballots cast in the wrong precinct, and another that banned the collection of absentee ballots by anyone other than a voter’s relative or caregiver. The ruling effectively invalidated what little protections were left in the 1965 Voting Rights Act, the landmark law that banned voting discrimination.
